entry.title: Refresh Development System

i need to Refresh Development System from Production, i need a best practice from SAP 

Specifically, we are on SAP RISE and using a Private Cloud (On-Premise).

entry.title: Avoid creation of duplicate condition contract
entry.content:
Dear Expert,

We are using SAP S/4  HANA-2023 on premise. system is allowing to create duplicate condition contract (for same customer, same validity period & same conditions). there is no duplicate entry check if there is an identical condition contract.

Can you please check what configuration is required to avoid creation of duplicate condition contract?

Thank you,

Rahul

entry.title: Derivation of Profitcenter in PM-Order
entry.content:
When creating a PM-Order the Profit center is taken from Material master. When a responsible Cost center is entered it should overwrite Profit center from Material master with Profit center of responsible Cost center. But it doesn't work.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Translation of Notification for Workflow (Flexible Workflow)
entry.content:
Dear,
the flexible workflow functionality in sales creates push notifications in the Fiori Launchpad. The texts of these push notifications can be changed in transaction SWDD_SCENARIO, e.g. for Workflow Scenario WS01800180 (sales orders without charge) the push notification for the release of a sales order without charge (task id TS01800245) can be changed. For example, the change of the notification text including sensitive information can be changed and will be saved in database table SWFSNOTIF_TXT. 

However, I am only possible to maintain such a notification text in different languages by signing into SAP GUI with the needed langugage. For example, I need to sign in with French to change the push notification text in French. Is it possible to maintain translations for push notification texts in a more convenient way?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Multiple schedule lines getting clubbed
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We have observed an issue, and would like your assistance. While creating a contract lets say 3010000010 - Line item - 10 -

Schedule line 1 - 10 qty and date 19.07.2025

Schedule line 2 - 10 qty and date 19.08.2025

Schedule line 3 - 10 qty and date 18.09.2025

With reference to this contract we try creating a sales order - in this sales order we observe that the 3 schedule lines are getting copied as one schedule line with date 19.07.2025 and qty 30. 

We need the schedules to be copied from contract to sales order without getting clubbed. 

Would you please let us know how to achieve this solution?

Regards

entry.title: WS533 Error during SD Settlement – Tax Code Not Determined
entry.content:
Hello,

When performing the final settlement of a customer condition contract via transaction WB2R_SC, I encounter the following error: WS533 – Tax code could not be determined via pricing; check customizing.

Context:

  • Transaction: WB2R_SC

  • Contract type: 25 – Customer Condition Contract

  • Action: launching the final settlement

  • Source documents: 3 sales orders

  • Pricing procedure is correctly maintained in the contract

Findings:

  • Both the customer and the material master data contain the relevant tax information

  • The source sales orders include the ZTAX condition, which is calculated correctly

  • The error occurs only during the final settlement

  • No lines are generated in the settlement document

Question:
Has anyone faced this issue in a similar scenario? Any ideas on how to fix or bypass this issue?

Thanks in advance for your support!

Business requirement is to have an additional operation during new order creation through notification.

Please suggest possibilities to achieve this requirement. 

Thanks and Regards
Jagadeesh

entry.title: Random Error message when performing time confirmation in find order operation F2173
entry.content: When  we try to perform time confirmation in find order operation app F2173 without any value in the personnel number field, the resulting error message  which is random and does not have enough  explanation for the details of the error. We need to have a clear message indicating the personnel number in the time confirmation is missing. Do we have amy OSS note to fix this problem.

entry.title: Rejected Lines still showing in MD04 (S4)
entry.content: We are having repeated issues with rejected sales order lines still being listed in MD04. They can be cleaned up with ATP_VBBE_CONSISTENCY, but we want to know what we can do to prevent this from happening.

entry.title: cXML punchout catalog integrations with S/4 Hana
entry.content:
We are currently implementing punchout catalogs in our SAP S/4HANA instance. I did the configurations of these catalogs. But some of the catalogs cannot be connected. Those are cXML-based catalogs. OCI catalogs are working as expected. (We don"t have any SRM implemented.)

  1. Could you let me know why the cXML catalogs are not connected?
  2. is the any other configuration available to do the cXML catalog integrations?

entry.title: IK18 - mass deactivate multiple measurement documents
entry.content:
We are currently using transaction IK18 in SAP S/4HANA DIGITS, and we have a business need to mass deactivate multiple measurement documents at once. However, in the standard functionality, it is only possible to deactivate documents one by one — there is no option to select multiple entries and perform a mass deactivation.

I have already searched for a business function, user exit, BAdI, or enhancement that could allow this functionality, but I was not successful in finding anything available.

Could you please let me know:

  1. Is there any standard functionality, business function, or configuration that enables mass deactivation of measurement documents in IK18?

  2. If not, is there any recommended approach for implementing a custom development (e.g., BAdI, enhancement, or custom transaction/report) to achieve this?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Selective Data Transition: Functional Advantages of Selective Migration
entry.content:
Beyond Migration: Unlocking Business Transformation with Selective Data Transition

Many companies today face the challenge of transitioning their complex ERP landscapes to SAP S/4HANA. The pressure is on to not only modernize technically but also to position themselves functionally for the future. While traditional approaches often emphasize a purely technical migration, Selective Data Transition (SDT) offers a broader perspective: it enables companies to embed functional, organizational, and process improvements directly into the transformation without sacrificing valuable data or historical insights.

 

Shaping Transformation Instead of Just Migrating

At its core, Selective Data Transition is not simply about selective data migration. The migration approach becomes a strategic lever to actively shape the future ERP system. Companies are no longer bound to a one-to-one copy of their legacy systems. Instead, they can modernize processes, consolidate system landscapes, and integrate new functionalities – all with purpose and direction.

This is particularly valuable for organizations with highly customized and heterogeneous ERP environments. SDT provides the opportunity to shed legacy burdens while preserving historical knowledge – but only where it is truly needed.

 

Functional Realignment Within the Target System

One of SDT’s key strengths lies in the ability to implement functional innovations as part of the transformation, rather than delaying them until after go-live. From the outset, companies can tailor their new system to meet tomorrow’s business needs. Practical examples include:

  • Universal Journal: Consolidates all financial data into one harmonized structure. This allows consistent reporting, simplifies controlling, and significantly enhances external financial disclosures.
  • Business Partner Concept: Replaces separate customer and vendor master data with a unified business partner view, improving data governance, compliance, and end-to-end process integration.
  • Logistics Enhancements: Features like Advanced ATP (for more accurate delivery date commitments) or Embedded EWM (for modern warehouse management) can be selectively implemented during the transition.
  • Modern Reporting: Relevant data can be migrated in a structured way and integrated directly into advanced analytics tools, ensuring data quality, real-time access, and media-free reporting processes.

The crucial point: these innovations don’t need to be rolled out across the entire system. They can be implemented selectively where they create tangible value – in data-heavy areas, specific business units, or as part of pilot initiatives. Relevant historical data can also be transferred selectively to avoid disruptions in information flow. In this way, SDT becomes a catalyst for innovation, process modernization, and functional excellence in the new ERP environment.

 

Targeted and Flexible Data Migration

Beyond functional realignment, SDT offers a high level of flexibility on the data side. Companies maintain full control over which data to migrate, from which sources, and to what level of detail.

This means not everything is carried over, only what is relevant to the future system is migrated.

Examples include:

  • Selective migration of clients, company codes, or plants, for instance, in carve-outs or acquisitions.
  • Restructuring of organizational units, allowing alignment with future governance models or regional business needs.
  • Legacy data archiving: only the necessary data is transferred into the new system. This keeps the target system lean, reduces maintenance costs, and simplifies operations.

Even for transactional documents, historical records, or configuration settings, a selective approach is key: Which periods should be retained? Which document types are still relevant? Which customizations must be carried over and which should be redesigned or retired?

The result: a clean, harmonized target system, free of unnecessary legacy data but still compliant with all legal, regulatory, and business requirements, striking an ideal balance between efficiency, compliance, and transparency.

 

A Structured Approach with a Clear Target Picture

The success of a Selective Data Transition relies heavily on a clearly defined target picture and a robust methodology. SDT is not a plug-and-play solution, it is a strategically planned transformation process.

At the beginning of the selective migration planning stands one essential question: What should the future ERP system look like? To answer this question, further considerations are required, including:

  • Which processes should be standardized?
  • Which systems should be harmonized?
  • What data is truly relevant?
  • What functional improvements should be realized?

Based on this vision, a detailed analysis of the current landscape is conducted. This includes systems, processes, data quality, and custom developments. Often, the greatest challenge lies not in the technology itself, but in the lack of transparency.

Interactive workshops involving business and IT stakeholders ensure that the transformation is shaped collaboratively. This ensures that technical feasibility, business requirements, and strategic goals are fully aligned. Potential risks such as data inconsistencies, integration issues, or functional dependencies, can thus be identified early and addressed proactively.

 

SDT as a Key to Functional Excellence

Selective Data Transition is far more than just an alternative migration approach. It is a powerful strategic enabler for realizing functional benefits, modernizing processes, and taking an active role in shaping the transformation journey. Choosing SDT means more than adopting SAP S/4HANA. It means investing in a smarter, leaner, and future-ready version of your ERP system. For organizations that want to shape change rather than merely manage it, SDT is the ideal path forward into a digitally empowered future.

Discover more: Watch the full webinar recording now and learn how Selective Data Transition enables not just a technical migration – but transformation with real business impact.

entry.title: SAPFPAYM not triggered automatically after F110 / Manage Automatic Payments
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I am facing an issue with Payment Medium Workbench (PMW) in S/4HANA.
When I run F110 (or Manage Automatic Payments), the payment run finishes successfully, payments are posted, and the payment advice notes are generated.

However, the payment medium file (DME) is not automatically created.
I always need to go to SE38 and run SAPFPAYM manually to generate the payment medium file.

In Manage Payment Media, the status of my items is usually "Downloaded", and I cannot change it to "To Be Generated".

Here are additional details:

  • Payment method is correctly assigned to DMEE format (e.g., FI_PAYMEDIUM_DMEE_CGI_05)

  • Program RFFOAVIS_FPAYM is assigned in the "Printout/Data Medium" tab of the payment method

  • In DME Administration (DMEEADMIN), I can see my file with "Data transmitted to external" checked

  • No DME file is found in AL11 unless I manually run SAPFPAYM

My question:

  • How can I configure F110 so that SAPFPAYM is automatically triggered during the payment run, without having to execute it manually?

  • Do I need to adjust the Payment Medium Workbench (PMW) selection variant, or maintain a missing link in the payment method customizing?

  • Could the status "Downloaded" in Manage Payment Media block the automatic generation?

Any advice or guidance on customizing steps to make SAPFPAYM run automatically after F110 would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: Database instance on High-availability System using SWPM
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am planning to set up an S/4HANA 2023 production system in a clustered environment.

The landscape consists of 6 servers — 4 AIX servers (Node1, Node2,Node3,Node4) designated for the SAP installation and 2 SUSE Linux servers (Node5 and Node6) for the HANA database.

I have a query regarding the S/4HANA installation using SWPM.

I have completed HANA (Node5 & Node 6) and the ASCS installation on Node1 and the ERS on Node2.

Next, I plan to install the PAS on Node3, followed by the AAS on Node4.

My question is:

1. Is it Mandatory to install the Database Instance (High-Availability System) on Node3 before proceeding with the PAS installation, or can I skip this step and go ahead with the PAS setup directly?

2. What exactly happens or what activities are performed if the Database Instance is installed on Node3 prior to the PAS installation?
If this is required, please confirm whether the Database Instance must be installed specifically on Node3.

3. What are the implications or consequences of skipping the Database Instance installation on Node3 and proceeding directly with the PAS installation?

Regards
Appuru

entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction:

Hello everyone, Myself Sriram Balaji, I am currently working as an SAP FICO Consultant. Last year, I got an opportunity to work in SAP Public Cloud Greenfield Implementation Project. During the “FIT to Standard” and “UAT” sessions, we have demonstrated the SAP standard Customer / Supplier Aging Analysis Report to the client but they are not satisfied with the standard aging report. They required a tailored Aging Analysis Report for Customer and Supplier, one that aligned perfectly with their unique operational requirements. This experience highlighted the importance of understanding client expectations beyond standard functionalities and fueled my journey into customizing SAP solutions in the Public Cloud.

In this blog, we are going to explore how we can develop Customized Customer (AR) Aging Analysis Report using the “Key User Extensibility” in the SAP Public Cloud.

 

Purpose of Preparing Customer Aging Analysis Report:

Customer Aging Analysis Report, is a basic financial report which provides the information of outstanding payment from the customer’s and how long they are due for the payment by categorizing into the Aging Buckets (0 – 30 Days, 31 – 60 Days, ……. Above 365 Days).

The aging report provides vital information to management to evaluate how effective the business is at converting sales to cash. The aging report is also used as a tool for estimating potential bad debts, which are then used to revise what is known as the allowance for doubtful accounts.

 

Key-User Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud:

Extensibility covers a broad spectrum of topics that enable customers and partners to adapt standard business software to their business needs.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud key user extensibility allows adapting standard functionalities to user requirements without the need for any external tools. Key User Extensibility is done in the customizing tenant of the development system through SAP Fiori apps designed to facilitate someone making small changes to apps, reports, and email and form templates without any coding experience.

Here's an overview of the things you can do using key user extensibility tools:

  • Change and adapt the UIs for SAP Fiori Apps
  • Create Custom Fields
  • Create your own custom templates or extend the standard forms and email templates
  • Create customer-specific CDS Views
  • Enhance the current business process by creating custom business logic
  • Create a new custom user interface
  • Create custom business objects

SAP S/4HANA embodies key user extensibility tools, which are completely web-based. They are targeted at key users who have a deep knowledge of the product itself, but not necessarily a very deep technical knowledge.

For more details about Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud, please refer the link https://extensibilityexplorer.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/ExtensibilityExplorer/#/ReadMore

To develop the Customized Customer Aging Analysis Report, we are going to use the below Key-User Extensibility Apps and other provided Apps by SAP in the Public Cloud:

  • Custom CDS View APP
  • Custom Analytical Queries APP
  • View Browser APP
  • Custom Catalog Extensions APP

My prior experience in developing Aging Analysis Reports in SAP ECC and S/4HANA GUI with my technical team allowed me to apply the same logic to Custom CDS Views and Custom Analytical Queries, even without knowing any deep technical knowledge.

Let me summarize the business requirement for Customer Aging Analysis before jumping into the technical steps involved for the development:

  • The report should display: Customer Account, Customer Name, Document Number, Line Item, Document Type, GL Account, Payment Terms (with descriptions), and other required fields.
  • The report should calculate and present: Overdue Days, Not Yet Due, Aging Buckets (0-30 days, 31-60 days, …... and Above 365 days), and Total Overdue Amount.
  • The report balances must be matched with the 'Manage Customer Line Items' App (Accounts Receivable Ledger).

 

In this Part - 1, We will explore how we can utilize the Custom CDS View APP for the AR Aging Analysis Report development.

 

Custom CDS View:

Custom CDS views can serve different purposes: They can be consumed in analytics or serve as external APIs to be consumed in external systems, for instance the SAP BTP. Especially Cube or Dimension views can be used in analytical scenarios and also you can create or modify a custom CDS view by,

  • Adding fields from multiple data sources.
  • Creating your own calculated fields.
  • Refining the properties of the selected fields.
  • Creating and maintaining parameters for the usage within your view.

We have combined the multiple data sources such as I_JournalEntryOperationalView, _I_GLAccountText, and _I_PaymentTermsText to create a Custom CDS View by using the Join Condition.

 

Step – 1: Open the APP – Custom CDS View

Click on “Create”.

 

Enter the “Label”, Choose the “Scenario” – “Analytical Cube” and Click on “Create” Button.

Note: By choosing the Scenario as “Analytical Cube”, We can use this CDS View to create an Analytical Queries for the Customer Aging Analysis report.

 

Step – 2: Choose the Primary Data Source 

Click on “Add” Button

Choose the “Primary Data Source”

Note: Data Source is an object containing the key figures and characteristics from the database and it provides a multidimensional analytical view of business data.

 

Select the respective “I_JournalEntryOperationalView” Data Source from the list.

 

This I_JournalEntryOperationalView CDS view provides access to all details of a journal entry item (database table ACDOCA) joined to the details of the corresponding operational accounting document item (database table BSEG) and to the details of the corresponding journal entry header (database table BKPF) including the most important business entity, such as G/L account, Cost Center or Profit Center.

So, this I_JournalEntryOperationalView is similar to the ACDOCA Table which contains the values of all the relevant fields related to the Accounting Document.

 

Step – 3: Choose the Associated Data Sources

Click on “Associated Data Sources”

Note: Associated Data Sources will help us to combine the two different data sources into one CDS View by using a join condition set between two or more equal characteristics present in the Primary Data Source – A and Associated Date Sources – B that contains the same data type.

For Example:

The primary data source "I_JournalEntryOperationalView" does not include the "Payment Terms Description" field. Therefore, we must join it with the associated data source "I_PaymentTermsText" using a join condition to retrieve this field.

Select the “Join Condition” Icon.

 

Click on “Add”

 

Choose the common field that available in the both Primary & Associated Data Source to join.

 

Select the Value Type as “Field”

Click on F4 in the Value Field.

 

Find the corresponding "Payment Terms" mapping field in the Primary Data Source to link it with the field in the Associated Data Source.

 

Select the Value Type as “Session Variable”

Choose the Value as “System Language” and Click on “Close” button.

 

Step – 4: Choose the Elements (Fields) to be added in the CDS View

In the Elements Section, Click on “Add” button and Choose “Elements”.

In the Elements selection pop up screen,

Choose the “Elements (Fields)” from “I_JournalEntryOperationalView” you want to display in the CDS view and then Click on “OK”.

Total 142 Elements (Fields) have been selected for the CDS view.

 

Step – 5: Create User Defined Parameters

User-Defined Parameters:

Parameters usually require data input when your custom CDS view is executed. This data can then be used like a variable e.g. in filters, calculated fields or even in a join condition to another view. You can then refine them or just create your own parameters if you need them.

The Customer Aging Analysis Report will operate based on "Open Items at Key Date," mirroring the functionality found in reports like "Manage Customer Line Item" or "FBL5N."

The "Open Items at Key Date" logic ensures that when the report is run for a specific date (which can be in the past, present, or future), it will only display items that meet following criteria mentioned below:

  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were not yet cleared as of the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared after the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared before the specified key date will be excluded from the report.

This "Key Date" will serve as a crucial input on the report's selection screen, driving the logic for determining which open items are included in the Customer Aging Report.

In the Parameters Section, Click on “Add” button,

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Data Type: “DATS” – Date (YYYYMMDD Format) Data type of the parameter.
  • Default Type and Value: “Manual” - Enter a manual parameter value in accordance with the data type syntax, e.g. for the data type DATS enter a manual value in the format YYYYMMDD.

Now the “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter is created. 

 

Step – 6: Add User Defined Parameters in the Elements (Fields)

In the Elements Section, Click on “Add” Button and Choose the “Parameters”.

Select the created “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter and Click on “OK” button.

Now the “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter has been added in the Elements.

 

Step – 7: Using “Filter” Applying the Logic for the Customer Aging Analysis Report

You can filter the information shown in your custom CDS view by setting up a condition, just like using the WHERE clause in SQL. This condition provides the view exactly what data to show.

Think of it like this:

The CDS view (I_JournalEntryOperationalView) which we are using that shows all the Accounting Document transactions in line item wise.

  • If you want to display only Customer related Accounting Transactions, you'd set a condition like "Account Type is equal to “D".
  • Or, if you only want to see Normal Transactions (Invoices, Payments) & Special GL Transactions (Advances), your condition would be "Special GL Code equal to “BLANK”, & “A”.

Once you set this condition (using either a simple editor or a form-based one), your CDS view will automatically filter its results, showing only the open items that match what you asked for. It's a way to fine-tune the data you see without having to look through everything.

We can use the form-based version to define simple filter conditions. In case you want to define more complex conditions, we can use expression-based version. Here, we have used expression-based version.

As per business requirement, to ensure the Customer Aging Analysis Report balances match with the "Manage Customer Line Items" balances, we've set up specific conditions for these fields: Account Type, Special GL Code, Posting Date, and Clearing Date in the Filter section using expression-based version.

 

Step – 8: Create Calculation Elements (Fields) – Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days

In the Elements section, click on “Add” button and Choose “Calculation” to create Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days fields for the report.

  1. Overdue Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as “Function” and Choose “Function Type – Date and Time”
  • Choose the respective “Function - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN” and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on “Create”.

Note: The function DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN calculates the difference between two specified dates, date1 and date2, in days. The actual parameters must have the predefined data type DATS and should contain a valid date in the format YYYYMMDD.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Overdue Days is Open Items Key Date (which was created as parameter for report execution) MINUS Net Due Date. 

 

  1. Payment Terms Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as “Function” and Choose “Function Type – Date and Time”
  • Choose the respective “Function - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN” and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on “Create”.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Payment Terms Days is Net Due Date MINUS Baseline Date.

Created Calculation Elements (Fields) for the report.

In the Element Properties Section, Maintain the Aggregation method as “No Operation” for the created Payment Term Days & Overdue Days Fields to convert the field into calculated measure for creating the Aging Buckets in the Custom Analytical Query APP.

 

Step – 9: Preview and Publish the created CDS view

In the Log section, check any error need to rectified before preview the CDS view.

Click on “Preview Data” button to display the values are coming as per the logic or not.

 

Created CDS View no of line items are matching with the Manage Customer Line Items.

Calculated Fields (Overdue Days, Payment Terms Days) are displaying with values in the CDS View according formula we have applied in the calculation function.

Once Check is successful, Go to “Next Steps” section.

Click on “Publish” button to publish the Created CDS View for Creating Analytical Queries.

In Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.
